Name: Jabberwocky
Description:
Players try to uncover the hidden Wild Word and to trick players into thinking that you hide the Wild Word.

Players write anything they want - a blurb or short story as the timer permits to either hide the Wild Word, or to fool other players into thinking your story contains the Wild Word.

Name: Alphabattle
Description: Two players write down a 6-letter-word behind the word hatch on a plastic word panel and take turns trying to guess the opponents words by guessing a certain letter. The opponent answers with "lower" or "higher", which is "marked" with arrows on the panel to help find the word.

Name: Pairs or Better
Description:
From the back of the box:

"The object of the game is to collect cards to form a five-card poker hand by landing on designated squares along the edges of the board, and then to exit the game.  The player to exit a hand worth two pairs or better ends the round and wins half the pot; the holder of the highest hand wins the other half."

"Pairs of Better uses the YOUR WAY playing system which provides highly interactive play with all players in competition right to the end."

According to their web site, all the inventor's profits go towards helping emerging opera artists, by way of supporting the Canadian Opera Company Ensemble Studio!

Name: Parole
Description: Two players attempt to make a chain of words and cross the board. Your adversary can and will try to break the chain and steal your words. Whoever reaches the other side of the board despite this handicap, wins the game.

Name: Race Across
Description:
Race Across is a puzzle game.  A battery operated car (which can operate at two speeds) starts at one set of flag posts and you place tiles that cause the car to turn and twist through a maze you build to get to the finish line.

Designed to be playable by 5+ with fairly big chunky colorful tile pieces.

Name: Hunt the Higgs
Description:
Hunt the Higgs is an educational card game intended to introduce schoolchildren to a few of the basics of particle physics. Cards represent "bosons", "final states" and experimental events.

Players take turns in trying to pair a boson with a final state from their hand to make as a high a score as possible. These scores are hidden from other players and the player with the highest card combinations at the end of the game wins.

An elements of tactics is introduced with the experiment cards which can either boost your own experiments or interfere with those of other players. Play of one of these experiment cards is the mechanic that causes the game to end.

Name: Grid Master
Description: Grid Master is played with a 1d30 on two separate boards. Players monitor the control of territory on the first gameboard and monitor the influence on territory on the second gameboard. The first player to position an army in  five consecutive territories in a straight line wins the game.

Name: Monkeying Around
Description:
From the box:

Carefully hang the monkeys on the palm tree.  The more monkeys that hang, the more of a chance that the palm tree will fall and the monkeys will scatter:  The first player who can hang all of his or her monkeys on the tree successfully, wins the game!

Similar to:

    Monkey Business
    Hanging Monkies

Name: The Mr. Men
Description:
9 sets of 4 cards, each depicting one of Roger Hargreaves' classic original Mr Men. The pack is used for a series of snap  and pelmanism (memory)type children's games. Age 4+

Characters (for those who like to know):
Mr Messy
Mr Bump
Mr Tickle
Mr Happy
Mr Daydream
Mr Topsy-Turvy
Mr Nosey
Mr Greedy
Mr Sneeze

Name: Hello Friends
Description:
From the SimplyFun website:

Konnichiwa, Hola, Guten Tag, Ni Hao, Bonjour!

Have fun playing a card matching game while learning to say HELLO in six languages. Players take turns laying down cards which match the languages played, or using wilds and goodbyes that have all the languages listed. The first player to play all his or her cards wins the game.

Game contains 54 illustrated playing cards and rules cards.

Name: Mörderische Dinnerparty: Die Stimme aus dem Jenseits
Description: London, 1951: You are invited to the reading of the will of Edward the 13th Lord of Facelift who died a week ago under mysterious circumstances. His lordship descends from a impoverished nobility and earned a fortune as a plastic surgeon. Especially is reputation to be discreet provided him with rich costumers from upper class. But his heirs also have a lot to hide...

Name: Parade
Description:
On a small board 4 x 10 squares there are six little half-precious stones for each player in their starting position: three in the first of the four-square-rows, leaving the rightmost square unoccupied and three in the sixth row, leaving the leftmost field unoccupied. The direction of play is "the long run", so the second row of each player is already "behind" the second row of the opponent. Stones can be drawn one step forwards or diagonally forward at each turn, never sideways or backwards. The stones cannot be beaten or jumped over and on each square there is only one stone allowed.
The aim of the game is to build a 4-stones-in-a-row "parade", horizontally, vertically or diagonally, which is not that easy as it first seems ...

This game was part of a small edition for the exhibition "Gott würfelt nicht" in Göttingen 2005, initialized by Reinhold Wittig, Althöfer and other game designers.

Name: Jenaer Turm
Description:
The board is one of the most simple: 4 squares in a square. The further material: 13 Dice with different letters on each side. The game is always played in two rounds. In the first one, player A is the "builder", player B the "killjoy", in the second round they change roles.
The "builder" begins drawing one die at random and throwing it. His task is it now, to stack the dice on the four squares, building towers as high as possible. There is only one rule for building: the letters of the next die on the stack must be further in the alphabet. The killjoy at his turn draws another die at random and throws it, but is trying to keep the towers low. It is free to both, on which of the four fields they put the die.
If it is impossible to put a die, the player can take the upper die of one tower away and lay it beside, so he can put the drawn one on the top. Therefore he should remember the letter on the die under the topmost.

The game ends after thirteen draws and the towers are counted: each tower counts the square of the number of dice it consists of: 25 for a tower 5 dice high, 16 for 4 ...
After two rounds the player with the higher score wins.

The Name "Jenaer Turm" is derived from a real tower in Jena, Germany, which is 26 stories high. The game was part of an edition of small games for the exhibition "Gott würfelt nicht" in Göttingen 2005.

Name: Melt Some Plastic
Description:
A tactical waragame using plastic toy soldiers and some home-made maps.

Rules available at:

http://www.freewebs.com/xxkalciferxx/wargamerules.htm

Name: Der Räuber Hotzenplotz
Description:
Up to four players start from one corner of a square board to bring six figures into the middle of the board. There is the den of the "Robber Hotzenplotz", a figure well known in Germany from a bestselling children`s book. Every player has his own way from "home" to the "den", equally laid out, and at first sight without any interaction or connection.

But:

Instead of dice there is a turning plate UNDER the board. On your way some of the points you walk on are holes in the upper board. So, if you step onto one of those, your figure stands on the plate underneath. Now is the time to turn the plate and watch: Is your figure falling into the trap (the box), because the plate has a hole at the same place, or does it keep standing?
Through the same turning mechanism numbers change in small window-like holes, telling each player how far he is allowed to go.
One more point: Figures you jump over just don`t count. So, if you jump, you go one step further.

The first figure reaching the den gains six points, the second five, the third and fourth four and so on. The winner is the player with the most points in the end.

Looks like a pure game of luck, but the step on a hole also changes the numbers for the other players. There are more twists you have to think of (e.g. a shortcut through the dark wood etc.), so for young children this can be the gate to "tactics" and "strategy": Is  my advantage worth the risk? And in which order shall I draw my figures? Because of the "jumped over doesn`t count"-rule, there are smart and dumb actions! And the winner is winning because of scoring points, not only, because he was the first!

Absolutely rare game and predecessor of euro-game-mechanics for young kids from the late sixties.

Name: Tri-Checkers
Description:
This game has the same object as traditional checkers: either capture all your opponents' men or trap them from moving. The difference in this case is that there are two opponents rather than one, and the last player standing wins.

The gameboard is adapted from an American board; that is, eight red-and-black squares along the home or back row with the dark square to the player's left. This board consists of three 24-square grids connected in a Y-shape. The fourth row of each grid is elongated and stylized to allow the board to connect.

The gameboard reverse is a typical, 8x8 American-style chess board. The game includes rules of play both for traditional checkers and Tri-checkers.

Name: Truth and Triumph: Challenge Edition
Description:
The Truth and Triumph - Challenge Edition provides additional questions which can be used with the base game.

Expands:

    Truth and Triumph

Name: Musical Assassins
Description:
A party game for large groups.

Players stand together. Each player secretly chooses someone to be his Bodyguard and a different player to be his Assassin. When the moderator starts playing music, each player moves and jostles about in an attempt to keep his Bodyguard positioned between he and his Assassin. When the moderator stops the music, everyone freezes. If a given player's Assassin can see the player without interference, the Assassin shoots him.

Inspired by a popular improv activity.

Name: Triangular
Description:
From the publisher:

"This ingenious new geometric strategy game combines spatial visualization and free form play to give you a rich, complex gaming experience. Points are scored by forming the corners of equilateral triangles, but just seeing the possibilities may strain your eyes! Who knew triangles could be so much fun?"

Content: 1 red triangle, 48 triangles in two colors

The goal of the game is to build major equilateral triangles out of the own smaller triangles.
The player with the most triangles wins the game.

Name: Celebrity
Description:
From the box:

How would you describe Julia Roberts without ever saying her name? How would you charade Jacques Cousteau?

In Celebrity, you try to get your team to guess the names of celebrities in 6 different categories ranging from entertainment to sports without ever saying the celebrity's name!

The same celebrity names are used for all three rounds but the clues become more difficult and hilarious as the rounds are played.

The players create the celebrity names for each game, making Celebrity timeless -- and unique every time you play.

Based on the public domain game known as Celebrities.

Name: Explore-A-Saur
Description:
From the publisher:

EXPLORE-A-SAUR Game and Book Set
Thinking & Problem Solving, Social & Emotional

It's a totally prehistoric experience! Read the book to learn fascinating dinosaur facts, then answer questions about dinos on the quiz cards. Realistically detailed dinosaur figures - each identified on its base - are great for creating scenarios or playing the enclosed game. Game board is 16" x 16" (28cm x 28cm) Includes 16 plastic dinosaur figures, 36 quiz cards and 4 game pieces.

From 6 years & up

Name: Mind's I
Description:
From International Playthings:

Questions about words, numbers, pictures, music, movement and memory will challenge players as they move along the game board.  Fast Track cards allow for hints when the questions get tough, so players don't get frustrated as they play.

Re-implemented by:

    Mind's I: Junior Edition

Name: Mawari-Sugoroku
Description:
E-Sugoroku or Picture Sugoroku is Japan's version of the roll-and-move race game. This entry in the BGG database serves for the myriad versions and themes used in E-Sugoroku, which include religion, travel, theater and more.
The earliest mentions of E-Sugoroku are of Pure Land Sugoroku, where the objective of the game is to reach the Pure Land, the Buddhist Western paradise. In the 17th Century, E-Sugoroku became popular with beautiful art on boards depicting the journey from Kyoto to Edo, or scenes of famous Kabuki actors. A second wave of popularity occurred in the 19th Century, after the Meiji Restoration, at which time it also became more of a children's game. Today, E-Sugoroku sets feature contemporary themes and can be found in toy-stores and 100-yen shops. 
A feature of E-Sugoroku is that dice rolls do not always translate into the same number of steps. Instead, progress from one step to the next could be made only by rolling specific numbers, or different numbers could indicate different paths to be taken.
E-Sugoroku should be distinguished from Ban-Sugoroku (BGG entry at Sugoroku), a game with an earlier origin and which is more akin to Backgammon. The generic term Sugoroku literally means 'double six' and is applied to board games that use dice.

Reference: Masukawa Koichi, Scenic Views: E-Sugoroku. In: Asian Games: The Art of Contest. Asia Society, 2004.

Name: Hour of Glory: Bunkerstorm
Description:
From the publisher's website...

Command the world's elite in this close-quarter battle expansion.  In Hour of Glory: Stronghold Kit, you learned the craft of stealth and guile.  Now in Bunkerstorm you must prove your skills as a leader and take the stronghold by storm.

Control a team of 5 soldiers in a desperate mission to capture and hold the objective.

This expansion contains:
• Bunkerstorm Battle Manual
• 5 white metal 28mm Fallschirmjäger miniatures
• 5 white metal 28mm British Paratrooper miniatures
• 1 deck of playing cards
• 2 play sheets
• 5 dice

Expands

    Hour of Glory: Stronghold Kit

Name: Crossing The Plains
Description:
LDS family trivia board game from 1984 - "Crossing the Plains".

A Pioneer Trek Simulation Game.

Based on the actual experiences of the first Mormon pioneers.

Copyright 1984, Deseret Book Company.

Contents: 
Game Board 
6 Playing Pieces 
Dice 
Crossing The Plains Cards 
Play Money 
Supply Record Sheets 
Instructions

For 2 – 6 players, ages 8 to adult.

The object of the game is to have the most points when all of the players have reached the Salt Lake Valley and thus become the “best pioneer.”

Created by Allan K. Burgess and Max H. Molgard. An educational and fun game for the whole family! Wagons ho!

Look for it in Deseret Thrift stores.

Name: Revenge of Monster Island
Description:
Revenge of Monster Island adds the setting of Tokyo city to the Monster Island game.  It includes the landscape of the city as well as its various military and civilian forces.  There are rules for urban monster fights, and new powers for monster creation.

The game is an expansion to the Monster Island series, and requires both Monster Island and Escape from Monster Island to play.  For UFO attacks on Tokyo, Invasion of Monster Island is also required.

Expands:

    Monster Island and Escape from Monster Island (requires both)
    Invasion of Monster Island

Name: Orange Barrels
Description: Players are highway drivers in the never-ending maze of road construction.  The object is to maneuver your car from start to finish before other players, in the process navigating through the obstructions created by various road obstacles, the most plentiful of which are the orange barrels (which other players are constantly placing in your path).

Name: Rrrum um's Eck!
Description:
"Rrrum um's Eck!" or "Rrround the Corner!"

Over the years Spielbox magazine has published some great games in its magazine. Usually they are originals by well-known authors that have appeared nowhere else, and at times they were so good that they were later appeared in full-on productions. Sometimes they were welcome reprints of highly regarded and hard to get games (3m's Jati). Exactly what prompted the republication of this old German children's game is better left the mystery it is, as there is very little remarkable about it. Maybe it was a great game by 1931's standards, but the German market by 1986 should have left a game like this in a corner best forgotten.

It is what can be typified as a Snake-and-Ladders game without the ladders, or 1-pawn Ludo with traps in which the prettiest girl may start. Players make their way with a single pawn from start to finish along a track of 6 rows, each 7 spaces long. The last square (on each row end before turning the corner) is a trap. When a player's pawn lands in one of those traps it will be sent back to square one, but not before a 6 is rolled to release the pawn from the trap. The only quicker way to start all over again is when another player lands in the same trap, because any player ending a move on another pawn's square sends that pawn back to the very beginning. Can it get worse? Yes, by landing in the last trap, because you get an immediate "mercy" die roll. A 6 means instant victory, any other number rolled will mean permanent removal from the game.

Maybe it was a reminder how far German game design had progressed in the 55 years since 1931. Saying that, it probably takes some considerable skill to make a game that is worse than Snakes-and-Ladders into a classic that warrants a reprint in one of Germany's most respected game magazines. What were they thinking.

Publishing history: this classic German family game can be traced back all the way to 1931 and appears to have been in print for a while. Much later it was reprinted by Spielbox magazine (4/1986 Aug-Sep) as one of the earlier entrants in the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series. It was presented with the original artwork and with an exact replica of the original rules.

Name: Nature Trail Game
Description: Try to be the first player to collect a set of 8 "friendly" tiles, while avoiding "danger" tiles.  If you do get a "danger" tile, you can get rid of it by drawing a "person" tile.  The "friendly" tiles include the Butterfly, Snail, Frog, Owl, and Daffodil tiles.  The "danger" tiles include the Tin Cans, Car Fumes, and Broken Bottles tiles.  No reading is required to play the game.

Name: Chemplay
Description:
Chemplay is a simulation game developed by Esso Chemicals in Europe to teach employees how to handle the "economic and business concepts of the petrochemical industry." The goal of the game is to do business and not be eliminated by going bankrupt in a mechanism very similar to Monopoly. There are two types of roles for the players, either Chemical Companies or Merchant Bankers (with about one third of the players being Merchant Bankers). All players rolls two six sided dice and move their marker along the track that many steps, paying rent to the owner or buying the property if it is not owned.

The Merchant Bankers usually acts as bankers and loan money to the Chemicals Companies, at terms that are up to the players to negotiate, but can own some properties (Pipelines and Transport Companies). The Chemical Companies can own Chemical Plants, of which there are six types, including the special "Steam Crackers" that enhance the other plants, but not Transport Companies and Pipelines.

Any player can take loans from the game's bank, the International Bank, when buying properties or developing a property but only up to 50 % of the needed amount and always at 20 % interest. If any player needs more money or there is a need for money when the player have to pay for the rent of a property, a board meeting requires money or the taxes are due, then that player may negotiate a loan with any of the Merchant Bankers (up to 80 % of the required sum, but at any interest rate and terms the players agree upon).

Apart from properties the game board consists of Board Meetings (when the player might gain or loose money), taxation and income.

When a player cannot pay, not even by selling property to some other player or by taking a loan, then that player becomes bankrupt and a special meeting is held among the creditors. The purpose of this meeting is to strike a deal where each creditor gains as much as possible and at the same time the bankruptcy is prevented. If such an agreement cannot be reached, the player is bankrupt and is eliminated from the game.

Name: Munchkin Sammlerbox
Description:
This is a box with room for all Munchkin games released to date. It includes 6 official oversize Munchkin dice as well as 14 dice cards and 16 new cards never before seen.

Expands:

     Munchkin


Part of the Munchkin series

Name: Kastell-Castello
Description:
Here is a description of the game from Spielbox:

At first glance, Kastell-Castello by Niek Neuwahl looks a lot like Cathedral. It is, however, quite different. The game is played with 2 players. Each player has 7 building elements in the form of different tetrominos which are the be placed onto an 8x8 game board. The player who can place the last building on the board wins.

To make sure the board is variable, there are 3 trees which are freely placeable onto the board before starting. According to the author, that makes for over 4000 different variations. The game also comes with 6 play variants.

Additionally to the regular sized edition, there's also a smaller version of the game which is about half the size of the regular version.

Online Play


     Jijbent.nl (Dutch: turn based)
     YourTurnMyTurn.com (English: turn based)

Name: Silly Soup
Description: Game consists of 4 collection bowls, 1 place-mat, 4 spoons, 16 marbles and one electronic motorized vibrating soup bowl.  The object of the game is to collect your color marbles from the bowl without collecting those of the other players while the motorized bowl vibrates, wobbles and spins around on the table.

Name: Loreley
Description:
Being a sailor is not easy. If basic navigation wasn't tricky enough, approaching any bit of rock that sticks out of the water somewhere, inevitably means being lured towards your death by the mesmerizing singing of a local hair-combing siren. Loreley, sitting on her rock, surrounded by the Rhine, is one of the more famous ones, and the German mythology is brought to life in this simple family game. Getting your boatmen from the boats surrounding the rock to the safety of the Loreley rock and reaching the fair maiden itself is what this game is all about.

Loreley sits on top of her rock in the center of the board, dutifully combing her hair. The Loreley rock is surrounded by 32 boats, and each boat has room for two to four boatmen. Players will first have to get all their 12 boatmen onto these boats, before the race to the top of the rock starts in earnest, by moving boatmen from the boats onto the rock itself. There are four tracks on the rock, one for each player's color, and all are exactly 11 spaces long. When a player places the 12th boatman on the rock Loreley is reached and that player wins the game.

Players start with 2 of their boatmen already placed on seats in the boats. By rolling the dice, these boatmen are moved from boat to boat. When a boatmen lands on a boat that already contains sailors, that player can place as many new sailors onto empty seats on the board as there are present in that boat before landing on it. You can't land (or place) in boats that are fully occupied. When all of a player's sailors are in boats already, instead of bringing a certain amount of new boatmen into play, that player can start to remove that same amount of sailors onto the rock and when someone's last sailor is moved from the boats to the rock, that player wins the game.

The game needs 3 or 4 players to work, and is mainly aimed at families with children around 7-9 years old.

Publication history: this game first appeared in a full production with Pelikan in 1973. "Altmeister" Rudi Hoffman's return to the game industry after a long illness was celebrated by the republication of his family classic by Spielbox magazine (5/1986 oct-nov), as one of the earlier entrants in the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series. The graphics of both publications are showing their age.

Name: Infantry Combat: The Rifle Platoon
Description:
"Infantry Combat: The Rifle Platoon" is "an interactive exercise in small-unit tactics and leadership" written by John F. Antal, the commanding officer of a tank battalion in Korea.

A pair of six-sided dice are required to play this solitaire game which is a variation on the Choose Your Own Adventure game book genre.

In Infantry Combat, you take on the role of a U.S. Army second lieutenant. "Your light infantry battalion has been airlifted into the Middle East on short notice, and now your platoon must defend Wadi Al Sirree against the superior might of an advancing enemy mechanized force . . . The scenario is highly realistic and is supported by maps and appendices with detailed specifications of the equipment and forces involved."

John Antal wrote three books which used this system: Armor Attacks, Infantry Combat, and Combat Team.

Name: Star Mogul: Ruins of an Empire
Description:
Star Mogul:Ruins of an Empire is a rule set for 28mm tabletop miniature wargaming sci-fi campaigns.  The publisher supports the game with a line of miniatures.  Accept the challenge of the distant stars and set up your own company on the frontiers of deep space...dare to become a Star Mogul!

From the publisher's site: 
http://www.alphaforgegames.com/starmogul.html

The game depicts the desperate struggle for survival following the discovery of a pan-galactic alien civilization, long since crumbled into ruins over 400,000 years ago...
 Large amounts of money were to be had by successful prospectors and salvage groups, if they could overcome the harsh and arduous environments, and return home with their alien trophies which might yield unexpected bounties to the human race.

The first wave of settlers and exploiters that mankind sent forth to the stars unwittingly unleashed an ancient pathogen that spread throughout the colonies before it fully revealed itself. Now the pathogen has played itself out, and it is time to rebuild what was lost.

With enough money to buy a salvage starship, and employ a rough and ready crew, you can see the opportunities that await someone who can survive on the Outer Rim and gather the resources left behind from the ruins of two empires, one human, one alien.


Re-implemented as Salvage Crew.

Name: Armor Attacks: The Tank Platoon
Description:
"Armor Attacks: The Tank Platoon" is "an interactive exercise in small-unit tactics and leadership" written by John F. Antal, a United States Army armor officer.

A pair of six-sided dice are required to play this solitaire game which is a variation on the Choose Your Own Adventure game book genre.

In Armor Attacks, you take on the role of the leader of a U.S. Army M1 Abrams tank platoon. "Throughout the work, you will have an opportunity to make life-or-death decisions, and the story will develop according to the choices you make. As you progress through the book you will learn important tactical and operational lessons."

Armor Attacks is illustrated and includes 11 maps. Appendices provide background information such as weapons data, friendly and enemy unit organizations, and tank fighting positions.

John Antal wrote three books which used this system: Armor Attacks, Infantry Combat, and Combat Team.

Name: Combat Team: The Captains' War
Description:
"Combat Team: The Captains' War" is "an interactive exercise in company level command in battle written by John F. Antal, a lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army. The book includes a foreword by Lieutenant General Tommy Franks.

A pair of six-sided dice are required to play this solitaire game which is a variation on the Choose Your Own Adventure game book genre.

In Combat Team, you take on the role of a U.S. Army captain commanding a company-size tank-infantry team in combat. "Combat Team hurls you into the turret of a main battle tank as you command a balanced company team (two M1A2 Abrams tank platoons and two Bradley mechanized infantry platoons) in battle."

Includes several maps and appendices with weapons data and data on the M1A2 Abrams.

John Antal wrote three books which used this system: Armor Attacks, Infantry Combat, and Combat Team.

Name: Alhambra: The Treasure Chamber
Description:
Description from www.spieltest.at:

The fourth Alhambra expansion stays true to the modular nature of the previous ones. So buying this expansion actually gets you four small expansions that can be combined with each other (as well as with those from previous expansions).

The new modules taken separately:

The Treasure Chamber
Filled to the brim with treasure that must be brought to safety. The treasure chests are worth points for being brought to buildings that match their color.

The Architect Cards
These have a double function. They allow an additional remodeling of your Alhambra, but can also be used as money cards.

The Bazaars
These add a new building type to the game. When built to their best use, they can bring up to 24 extra victory points. The points are gained by having buildings of matching colors built next to them.

The Attackers
The palace is being attacked. Lookouts keep a close watch for the attackers to try and figure out which direction the attack is coming from. This allows the player to build protective walls in that direction. Otherwise, they will lose points during the final scoring.

Expands:

    Alhambra

Name: Mörderische Dinnerparty: Tod im London-Express
Description: Great Britain in the year 1936. The entire commonwealth is in excitement since Edward VIII will ascend the throne this very week. The overnight express is on its way to the capital with passengers who would like to attend the coronation. But the journey takes an unforeseen twist: The conductor is found dead in his compartment. Only one thing is certain: one of the first class travellers is the murderer...

Name: INC.  The Game of Business
Description: You are the CEO of a large corporation.  During the course of the game, you buy and absorb small businesses into your corporation.  You also work to acquire enough employees to fully staff all of your businesses. You can occasionally swap stock and businesses with other players.  In addition, you can steal  employees from them.  The goal is to have $1 million in cash and have your corporation fully employed.

Name: Captain Planet and the Planeteers
Description:
After the animated series "Captain Planet". Gaia wakes up and sees planet earth in trouble. Captain planet and his five teammates from all continents try to work against some eco-villains who pollute the planet. Gaia gives the players magical rings and they identify with one of five elements and powers.
The figures now move around the different environments like mountains, towns etc. cleaning up the pollution (litter, smog, ...) by appropriate Earth Saver cards.
Sometimes Captain Planet helps doubling their efforts, but the Eco-villains also create more pollution, so the players try to put them to jail ...

Sometimes co-operative game for children from 6 to 12 years.

Name: Der Räuber Hotzenplotz
Description:
A co-operative game for children from 5 years up. The "Robber Hotzenplotz" from the well known book by Otfried Preußler, has stolen pieces from the grandmother`s cake and trying to get them safe in his hiding place. The players try to catch him and the pieces first.
There are four figures walking along square fields, in which the board (looking like a landscape)is divided. The Hotzenplotz-figure is independent from a single player. It walks after all four players rolled their dice and walks along a spiral way from the outside to his hiding place, crossing the squares. He always walks to and fro, stealing another piece of cake and gets it to his hiding place.
If he comes to a square with one of the four figures on it, he captures it. But if the players manage to place two figures on the square with the robber (otherwise it is forbidden to place two figures on one place!), then he is captured in prison and the piece of cake saved. Of course, the robber starts from the prison right away again to steal more ...
There are different variants, making it easier or more difficult for the players to reach the goal of saving four pieces and winning the game together.
Nice co-operative game for the youngest gamers, starting discussions after every dice-roll where the figures should walk.

Name: Iuvo
Description:
An abstract game for 2 or 4 players, played on a 7x7 grid, where players try to move their own playing pieces onto the start positions of the opposing player. First player to do so wins. A game can end prematurely when a player manages to capture all stones from the other player(s), or when all other players had to resign from the game because there was no legal move available in their turn.

There are 16 stones in play. Each player owns 4 stones, and the remainder are neutral. In a 4 player game there is an added twist as each player shares 2 of the 4 stones with other players. One with the player on the left, the other with the one on the right.

In the starting positions, all stones are isolated. Each turn a player can move a friendly or neutral stone the same way as the knight jumps in chess (two straight and one sideways in all directions). Initially, for as long as there are isolated pieces on the board, each piece has to jump to a space neighboring at least one other (a diagonal connection doesn't count). This way smaller and bigger groups will form, and this has to continue until all pieces form one single chained group. Once a group has been established, it is not allowed to break it up again, so after each jump there has to be a single chain present. It is also forbidden to move a neutral stone immediately after it has just been moved.

As soon as there are no isolated stones or groups left, "owned" pieces can be captured by landing on them. Neutral pieces can never be taken. A player wins when all his remaining pieces have reached their target, so losing a stone or two might not be a bad tactic.

A clever use of the knight's move, and the ability to capture pieces, coupled with the restriction to maintain a single group makes this far more than yet another Halma-variation.

Publication history: this game appeared in Spielbox magazine (1/1986 Feb-Mar) as one of the earlier entrants in the "Spiel zum Herausnehmen/Game to Remove" series. It later showed up again on the 2002 Göttingen Spieleautorentreff, where game designers meet to showcase their self-published inventions, in a wooden version with colored film-spool-lids as playing pieces. As far as I can tell Söncke's Iuvo has only ever been published in Spielbox magazine and it also remains his only published game to date (2006).

Name: Jutland
Description:
From the manufacturer's web site:

The Battle of Jutland was the famous naval battle between the British Royal Navy and the German High Seas Fleet during World War I. Jutland was the only major naval engagement ever pitting dreadnought class battleships against each other. From the start of WWI the German U-boat fleet tried to put a strangle hold on shipping and food entering Great Britain by sea and the Royal Navy put a similar naval blockade on all shipments heading for Germany. The Battle of Jutland occurred when the German High Seas Fleet entered the North Sea in force to renew a policy of raiding the English coast. The outcome of the battle would play a major role on the fate of the war in the west.

A fast playing two player game.

The Battle of Jutland Includes:
1)  2 piece, 17" x 22" color game map
2)  56 Full color German ship Counters
3)  17 Full color German Fleet Markers
4)  77 Full color British ship Counters
5)  20 Full color British Fleet Markers
6)  Game Rules
7)  D10
8)  4 1/2" x 5 3/4" x 1.5" Game Box
Families: Series: Compact Game Series (Guild of Blades)

Name: Penetration
Description:
You have different objectives and you can bluff your opponents on what your real objective is...  You have both offensive and defensive pieces. Each turn consists of 7 actions by each player where you can split the actions between either offensive or defensive pieces. Dice are for any minor conflict outside of an Objective area between an attacker and a defender piece. Each player will play a conflict card for a major conflict within your objective areas. Be careful as you can only use each card once until you have used your whole deck.

A bit like a sophisticated Stratego in some ways...

Name: O.R.B.I.T.
Description:
A game of maneuvering spacecraft to dock with a space station then intercept planets and then return to Earth.  The planets are in motion as well, so you have to plan the intercepts.  You use course correction cards for your maneuvering.

Game consists of a 13 1/2" X 13 1/2" jigsaw board, 36 cards, and 9 pieces representing the planets and ships.

Name: Die Teppichhändler
Description: The game theme is the auctioning of Arabian carpets.

Name: Bienen-Spiel
Description: Easy children's game - up to 4 players (ages 6+) move over a flower field in order to reach their home - only problem are occurring clouds.....

Name: EleMental
Description:
EleMental is a 3D strategy board game for ages 10+. Players take charge of the five EleMental forces of Earth, Water, Fire, Air and Time and battle it out across the EleMental planes to reach the center of the board - Creation.

Once a player has reached Creation they must build up a collection of EleMents to the extent that they are immovable, or better still, get all five types of EleMent onto the creation spot, thereby making an 'Ultimate' or 'Perfect Force'. An IMMOVABLE, PERFECT or ULTIMATE FORCE instantly wins the game.

How a player wins the game determines how many points they are awarded at the end; this points tally can be affected by throwing the EleMental dice. If a player is confident they will win they can throw the dice to multiply the points - multipliers range from 2x to 20x the winning points total.

Name: Click-Chek
Description:
This curious little game depends on magnetism for its play mechanism. Each player gets 6 little balls (called Clickets) with magnets inside them. four of the balls are bi-colored, so you can tell which end is which. However, the remaining two are a uniform color, which means you can't really tell which end is north or south in terms of polarity. There's a nifty wooden board with a grid of 3X4 shallow depressions. The game is simplicity itself - take turns placing a Clicket. If you cause two or more Clickets to click, you have to take them back. The winner is the first player to get rid of all his Clickets.

From the back of the packaging strip (also in Dutch and German):

How to play CLICK-CHEK
In turns,  one CLICKET is placed on the board.
The player that causes CLICKETS to click together has to take these CLICKETS back.
The player who first is rid of all his CLICKETS is the winner.

Name: Let's Go Apple Picking Math
Description:
A game to help children get an introduction to math.

Each player has an apple collecting basket and a tree shaped game card. Each game card starts with 10 apple chips on the tree.

Players each roll the three dice. The two red dice are standard D6 dice. The green die indicated a "+" or "-" symbol.  The player who rolled the dice must answer the math problem provided by the symbols showing. If they answer the math problem correctly, he/she takes one apple from their game card and places it in their basket. If they answer the math problem incorrectly he/she must take an apple out of the basket .

Turns continue until a player picks all their apples from their tree to win the game.

Name: Chocolate Chip Math
Description:
A children's game to help teach the basics of math.

Each player has a chocolate chip cookie scorecard with no chips on it to begin. Players work their way around the board, landing on spaces in which they must answer the math problem posed to them. If they answer the question correctly, they collect a chocolate chip to add to their cookie. The first player who fills his or her cookie scorecard wins!

The game board has two sides. One side is an addition and subtraction game. The other side is a multiplication and division game. The instructions are the same for both sides. Just the level of difficulty of the math problems changes.

Name: Deflection
Description:
Maneuver your discs in patterns of ricochet movement and try to capture all of your opponent's discs.

Whenever a disc is moved, it always in a ricochet pattern, with at least one deflector serving as a guiding device to determine the possible angles of movement.

Name: Battle of the Slag Hills
Description:
The final battle of the "War of the Ring."  This is the march on the gates of Mordor undertaken as a diversion to buy time for Frodo and Sam to achieve the ultimate goal: destruction of the One Ring.  The Mordor player wins if he is able to destroy all units of the Gondor player within 9 game turns.

This is a mini game included with the "The Siege of Minas Tirith"
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: The Hustings
Description:
From the back of the box:

"Welcome to the Hustingshire North Parliamentary Constituency, where your campaign to become its duly elected Member of Parliament is about to commence.

The Hustings is a fast moving and exciting game which follows closely the British electoral process and gives its players the chance to become candidates and experience the thrill and tension of participating in an Parliamentary Election.

Choose your Party, secure your nomination, and get your campaign underway as the race hots up in the pursuit of the votes available in the fourteen Wards of Hustingshire North. On your way, however, beware of the ups and downs and decisions you may have to make, all of which could affect the number of votes you secure.

Once all of the votes have been cast and the postal votes collated, candidates face the nail biting wait for the Returning Officer to open the ballot box, complete the count and declare the result of the Election.

The Hustings is easy to play and yet totally absorbing, great fun and educational at the same time. Above all it will provide hours of fun and excitement for al the family.

Experience the true flavour of the British electoral system and play The Hustings today. It's sure to get your vote!"

Name: Beeline
Description:
On a 16-hex gameboard (4x4 quadrilateral) of a honeycomb, two players each control three bees.  The object of the game is maneuver all of your bees so that they are adjacent to any one of your opponent's bees.  Either player may declare a "swarm" at the end of their turn, meaning that for the rest of the game, each player must move twice per turn.

This game was published in the March 2006 issue of GAMES Magazine.

It was reprinted in the August 2010 issue, on page 10. In this issue the board and rules were printed on the same page.

Name: Last Man Standing
Description:
Last Man Standing is a simultaneous-play gambling game.  Cards representing fighters are played one per round over five rounds by each player and 'paid' with coins equal to their value.  As fighters are defeated, their coins are collected by the winning fighter.  Players also put coins in a pot which is won at the end of the fifth round by whichever players have surviving fighters.  The player with the most money at the end wins the game.

Last Man Standing was first published as part of Chief Herman's Holiday Fun pack.  It was conceived on a road trip across Eastern Washington as a cross between Lamarckian Poker and Dogfight.

Name: Reef Encounter of the Second Kind
Description:
Reef Encounters of the Second Kind was released at Essen 2006.  It is an expansion set for Reef Encounter, introducing new creatures, opportunities, and tactics to the basic game.

The crown of thorns starfish with their voracious appetites have now found the reef and will consume any corals that they can reach.  Blue shrimps will assist host shrimps in protecting the larger corals, but these blue shrimps are notoriously unreliable.  Meanwhile, the polyp tiles now come in a variety of different forms, and even the rocks are liable to change shape.

A selection of cards provides one-off opportunities to influence the game, to introduce or to move the blue shrimps, or to affect the scoring at the end of the game.  An appropriate card is also required before a parrot fish can consume its first coral.

Name: Mein Hühnerhof
Description: Up to 4 players run a chicken farm - breeding, feeding, growing - players try to simulate a good working farm.

Name: Yarbles
Description: This is a 3 player game with a variant for 2 players.  The object of the game is to move your fighters and messengers around their designated routes to "home". The player to get all of his Yarbles men in home first is the winner.

Name: 1-2-3 Home Free
Description: This game is played just like the real playground game. One player is “IT” while the other players select a hiding place on the board. When the SEEKER finds a player, the race to home begins.

Name: Disorderly Conduct
Description:
Disorderly Conduct is the game that seems primarily focused at law students.  Comprising seven categories of traditional law topics, this trivia game has individual players or player-teams answering questions about Torts, Contracts, Property, Criminal Law, Evidence, Constitutional Law, and General Practice.  The questions are quite involved, and require players to have more than a passing association with the law and legal procedure.

In a similar vein to Trivial Pursuit, players seek to answer questions in each of the six law categories before moving to the middle to answer the question in general practice to win the game.  Unlike Trivial Pursuit, players make a decision from among four multiple-choice answers.

Name: Crescendo Chess
Description:
From the box:

"An introduction to an ageless game with a 20th century pace. The game of chess is simple. It is difficult only if you make it so. And Crescendo Chess is as simple as regular chess. It is played by the same rules. The chess men move the same. A full set of rules and instructions that completely cover Crescendo Chess are included. After several moves, you then enter into the exciting world of mobility, power, and cunning. Compounding the power and mobility of the chess pieces accelerates the game and sharpens one's perception of the effects of combining different pieces. Thus one gains a broader insight and a better appreciation of this game. Because of this, Crescendo Chess enhances regular chess.

"Crescendo Chess is a new experience for any chess player. By following the rather simple rules, one can soon learn to think in terms of stacking, capturing and position playing. One important feature in Crescendo Chess is that the chess men have a hole on top and one on the bottom that permits pegging one piece atop another. When this is done, it is called "stacking." A stack of chess men can then move across the board together. One soon learns not to exhaust the stack ineffectively. Experience teaches how to take advantage of the best stacking arrangements for certain types of attack and defense."

In one turn the stack moves first as the bottom piece normally would move as in regular chess, then continues as the next piece up would move, etc. It costs one turn to place a piece on a stack. On the next turn, the stack can make its move (see rule8). To give an example, a Knight can be placed atop a Bishop in one turn. Then, on a later turn, the two together would move the permissible diagonal move of the Bishop and the two together could continue, one - one, two, as the Knight would move."

"It is important that in stacking, the pieces are moved into the stack using their regular move, - that is, a Bishop diagonally, a Rook forward or sideways, etc. Each piece must be free to make its move as in regular chess rules."

"Crescendo Chess is so called because it starts as regular chess and then increases in intensity. As stated, the first two moves by each player are made on a regular basis. After that, the next four moves by each player may be made where one piece is stacked on top of another to a two level height.Max. (L2). NOTE: See Glossary & Game Notations at end of rules. It is not necessary to stack the pieces if the player does not wish to do so.

Upon completion of a total of six moves by each player, the pieces may be stacked to a three level height. Max. (L3). This is the stacking limit for the rest of the game. The three can move first as the bottom piece, which then remains, then as the other two would move as a two piece stack."

Name: Venerable Destruction
Description: This is a simulation of the final battle between the forces of Good and Evil on the planet Venerable.  The weaponry is akin to that used in 15th or 16th century earth warfare.  A bit of Magic is thrown in occasionally and the units sport somewhat 'colorful' names, e.g. The "Foul"  "Lowest of the Low" Fetor and the Sycophant for the forces of Evil AND "Khan" "Harem" and "El Touche" for the forces of Good, among others.  Although it is a 2-sided battle, actually many players can participate by being granted control by the supreme leader of each side; so even in excess of 10 players could theoretically participate in the game.

Name: Junior Mentalogy
Description:
Manufacturer's Description

How Many Cards Can You Remember?

Junior Mentalogy is designed for younger children. It's an exciting game that tests their memory skill with early learning fundamentals.

Colorful cards with the alphabet, pictures, numbers, and shapes are placed on the board. The object of the game is to reach the Mentalogy end zone by recalling all the different card selections. As the game progresses, more and more cards are added to the mix. The level of difficulty can be adjusted to suit your child's age.

Junior Mentalogy is a fun, entertaining game for young kids. Each game lasts around 15 to 20 minutes - the perfect beginners' game that kids will love to play again and again.

- perfect for young attention spans
-easy instructions and setup
-enhance their learning capabilities

Name: Come Play With Me
Description:
From the box :

"It's a great time for you to come play with me!

Let's go through the house and see what fun stuff we can find! Toys are everywhere! Balls in the living room, trains in the kitchen, bears in the bedroom. Look, I found the blocks! Can you be the first to collect all of the toys you need for your toy box? So many toys to find. Good thing it was so easy to find this great game!"

As usual - great quality components from Ravensburger. The box itself becomes the gameboard, as the floor and wall components insert nicely into the base. Wonderful colors will keep kids interested in this fun little memory/set collecting game. Roll the die...move from room to room...turn over a tile...only keep that toy if you do not already have that toy. The first player to have a complete set of all 6 distinct toys wins!

Sweet and simple. Just as we've come to expect from Ravensburgers' wonderful line of kid's games.

Designed for ages 3-6.

Name: Easy Come Easy Go
Description: Starting with $250,000, you must reach $1 million by moving around the board and collecting money.  You must deposit your money into your bank account and avoid being mugged by another player. You can borrow money, play the casino or trade commodities on wall street.

Name: The Safety Card Game
Description: Couldn't tell too much from the box - appears to be a memory/trivia game that helps kids learn about important safety facts like poisons and crossing the street.  Geared (per the box) at kids age 3 to 9.

Name: Symmetrix
Description:
This game is for ages 4 to 7.

Each player has a card that shows a three-by-three arrangement of nine common objects that have left/right symmetry - flower, butterfly, bridge, pants, etc.  However, the cards show only the left half of the objects.  The three card columns have one, two, or three dots at their top; the rows are marked with square, circle, triangle.  There are 36 tiles that show the right half of the objects on the cards.  These are placed face up (easy) or face down (hard) in the play area.

Two dice, one with 1/2/3 dots and the other with square/triangle/circle on the faces, are rolled.  The players must find the tiles that match the objects on their card corresponding to the intersection shown on the dice. Once found they put them on the card to complete the picture.

Older children might enjoy having the tiles face down to add some memory challenge.

Name: Ultimate Race
Description:
Description from the box:

The Ultimate Race is not an ordinary game: all is not dependent on luck. You will have to choose a car, select your tires, fight against temperature, and make judicious driving strategies to reach the first step of the podium. Six players will compete in a hot championship on 16 different world racetracks. The green flag is out, roll the dices and may the best man win!

Name: Quebec '75
Description:
Strategy & Tactics magazine #236.

They Died With Their Boots On, Volume 1: Quebec '75 is part of the first volume of "They Died With Their Boots On" system, which uses an interactive game turn in which both players command an overall force made up of several sub-commands. During each turn, players alternate picking "command markers," which designate the sub-command within their force they may then use to conduct operations. The player then moves units of that sub-command and, at the completion of its movement, conducts attacks with units of that same sub-command. Play then passes to the other player, who similarly picks a marker and moves and fights. That procedure continues until all command markers have been picked. Additionally, certain events cause players to pick "heroism markers" at random, which may generate anything from mad, impetuous charges to abject surrenders.

The rules are divided into the standard rules, which are common to all games in the system, and the scenario rules, which provide deployment and reinforcement instructions, as well as victory conditions, for each specific battle game.

In this game, each turn represents one to two months, depending on the time of year, and each hexagon on the map represents 9.3 miles (15 kilometers) across. Units of maneuver for both sides are battalions and regiments, artillery batteries, and  a few miscellaneous units of smaller sizes.
Families: Series: They Died With Their Boots On (Decision Games)

Name: They Died With Their Boots On, Volume 1: Custer's Last Stand
Description:
They Died With Their Boots On, Volume 1: Custer's Last Stand is part of the first volume of "They Died With Their Boots On", which uses an interactive game turn in which both players command an overall force made up of several sub-commands. During each turn, players alternate picking "command markers," which designate the sub-command within their force they may then use to conduct operations. The player then moves units of that sub-command and, at the completion of its movement, conducts attacks with units of that same sub-command. Play then passes to the other player, who similarly picks a marker and moves and fights. That procedure continues until all command markers have been picked. Additionally, certain events cause players to pick "heroism markers" at random, which may generate anything from mad, impetuous charges to abject surrenders.

The rules are divided into the standard rules, which are common to all games in the system, and the scenario rules, which provide deployment and reinforcement instructions, as well as victory conditions, for each specific battle game.

In this game, each turn represents from three days to three weeks, depending on the level of intensity of campaigning, and each hexagon on the map represents 12.4 miles (20 kilometers) across. US Army units are battalions (actually task-organized sub-divisions of regiments). Indian 'units' each represent groups of warriors, with about 80-120 individual per strength point.
Families: Series: They Died With Their Boots On (Decision Games)

Name: 1492: The New World – North America
Description: 1492 is not a game on its own but serves as an expansion to Europe 1483 and/or Europe 1483: Asia 1483.  It adds seven new playable nations, plus optional rules to upgrade three African nations to full player nation status.  With the addition of this expansion, the 1483 series can support up to 53 players in a single game.  Includes a large 49.5" x 31.5" map to add to the game.

Name: Roll-em Jack-Pot Dice
Description:
Any number of people may play.  Each player contributes 5 or more chips to the Jack-Pot before starting the game.

The staring player and those that follow each in their turn of play place one chip to the Jack-Pot for 1 throw of the dice.  Each Player is awarded or penalized by the Jack-Pot according to the symbols thrown.  FREE throws earned (1 Cherry with any 2 symbols) are taken before passing the dice.

The player pays Jack-Pot 1 chip for each Lemon in any throw of the dice.

Play continues rotating to the left until the luck player "Hits The Jack-Pot."

Name: Dino-War
Description: This is a proprietary take on the classic children's game War.  The game is played with a unique 36 card deck with three cards in each of 12 ranks, each represented by a different dinosaur.  The game is played until one player has possession of all of the cards.

Name: Be an Angel
Description: This game is a religious take on Old Maid where the player with the last card is an Angel.  The game comes with a unique 31 card deck where the cards represent things from well-known Bible stories.

Name: Branded The Game
Description: Object of game: Only one man survived the battle of Bitter Creek. Since there were no witnesses it was assumed the lone survivor had run as a coward. Having being discharged from his countries service with his sword broken and his insignia removed, he was a man BRANDED as a coward. As this man goes through life, he must demonstrate over and over his strength and courage in an attempt to clear and remove his unwarranted stigma of BRANDED. As you travel the trail you try to be the first player to show your courage by covering the name branded on the scoring line with discs won in battle at the various areas.

Name: Remember the Alamo
Description: The game recreates the battle of the Alamo which was fought on the outskirts if San Antonio de Bexar in 1836.  The Mexican player must successfully get his men inside the fort and the Texan player wins if he does not.  Each turn, the Mexican player spins; the outcome of this spin determines which side is allowed to draw a card.  The outcome of each turn is determined through card play in combination with the results of the spinner.

Name: Diffusion
Description:
Diffusion is a two player game which employs a Mancala board and a set of like-colored stones. Here a 2×6 board with 48 stones will be used. Initially the board is set up with four stones in each of the small pits and no stones in the large pits. Each player owns the 2×3 pit block to his left. The winner will be the first to empty all stones from their block.  Diffusion is a unique, robust addition to the family of Mancala games. Draws and ties cannot occur in Diffusion. Mark Steere invented Diffusion on January 20, 2006.

Online Play


    Super Duper Games
     Play Diffusion on games.wtanaka.com (real-time or turn-based)
     Play Diffusion v2 on games.wtanaka.com (real-time or turn-based)

Name: Tina, Tim und Wambolo
Description: Tina, Tim and Wambolo - on Berry Island in the Crocodile River is excitement till the very last move. Stranded on an island surrounded by crocodiles players have to collect berries and build a boat in order to escape - but this just works if they help each other....2-6 players ages 5+

Name: Cartel: A Game for Real Estate Tycoons
Description:
Yet another game named "Cartel".  Cartel is extremely similar to Monopoly in that you spin a spinner to move one to six spaces, visiting different countries (Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, England, France, Germany, Holland, Italy, U.S.A.) on the board.  You may purchase properties in the different countries.  If you land on a country with an opponent's properties, you must pay rent to that player.  Some facets of Cartel that contrast it from Monopoly are as follows:


     Each player may have houses in no more than five countries.
     There are no blocks of properties:  Each country has one space on the board.
     Once you land on a country space, you spin a spinner to determine whether you may build a house, may not build a house, or may build a house for free.
     If you land on Try Your Luck, you spin the Lucky Spin spinner, and win money from the bank or lose money to the pool.  If your spin showed LUCKY POOL, you get the money in the pool.

Name: Wiglin'
Description: You attempt to repeat what is shown on cards; these are intended to be funny movements.  Essentially the game was designed to be an ice breaker and not as contorting (is that a word?) as something like Twister,  Very silly graphics...

Name: Critter-Tek
Description:
Critter-Tek is a tongue-in-cheek stuffed animal parody of Battletech that was fully approved and licensed by FASA.  Instead of gigantic high tech robot mechs players construct mechanical TEKs that are powered by animals on treadmills with hamster powered gyros and paper mache armor.  Weapons include spit-wad blowguns, slingshots and left over fireworks.  In fact Critter-Tek uses all the standard Battletech rules and merely renames all the terminology to a furrier anthropomorphic animal genre.

This game includes the RPG TEK-Warrior.

USER NOTE:New elements, not include in standard Battlemech, such as subterranean movement for burrowing animals adds an new and interesting twist to a classic game.  This Beer & Pretzel approach to Battletech was a great way to introduce game mechanics to fairly young gamers.  My sons played allot of Critter-Tek while in grade school.

Name: Xtreme Limits
Description:
Here is a description of the game from Die Poppelkiste:

In Xtreme Limits, the timer's running. With the help of chips, a player can change the hand. The goal is to have the three hands in the right orientation once the time has run out. And there is one extra piece of meanness: If a hand is on 4 or 8, a player can switch his task card with another's.

Name: Jabberwacky
Description:
A game for two teams.  The teams take turns forming a word chain.  Words are recorded into the electronic unit before the time runs out.  Points are scored for the team having the last word in a chain.  The words are then played back in reverse order and the teams are given opportunities to recall the preceding words for extra points.

Recording the words in wacky ways is encouraged, to add humor to the game.  Rules on word-linking are lenient, and players can challenge words, but risk points doing so.

An example word chain:  Game…Play…Stage…Coach…Football…Sport…Poor…Rich…Aristocratic…Hereditary nobility…etc.

Name: Dix Petits Indiens
Description:
DIX PETITS INDIENS is a French game based on the murder mystery novel by Agatha Christie in which ten people on an island get murdered by 10 different methods.

The game board represents the island with the locations of where the 10 bodies can be found.  The 10 characters are represented on 10 red cards and the 10 methods of death by
10 blue cards. These are shuffled and placed face down on the 10 red and blue spaces on the outside of the board.

When it is his turn a player can (and must) carry out one of the following three actions:

1.    Simultaneously turn over one red and one blue card.  Look at their contents (in secret) and then return them face down to the spaces from which they came.

2.    Move his playing piece along one yellow line to a neighboring black or red space.

3.    Write down on a record sheet any information concerning the cards turned over in previous rounds.

The idea of the game is for players to work out where the matching red and blue cads are located and then move their playing piece to the appropriate location on the board to 'discover the body' (by turning over the two matching cards).  Successfully doing this earns the player one of 10 "little Indians".  Making a mistake means the player loses his next two turns.

The game ends when all 10 bodies have been discovered, with the winner being the player that discovered the majority of them.

Name: Great Play Baseball
Description:
A baseball simulation game (not using actual players) with a 100-card deck for randomization. Defensive player positions players on the field and declares pitch to throw; offensive player turns over top card on deck; players match the batters hitting ability (lefty-righty; .100, .200, or .300 hitter) with pitch. Can be strike, ball, or ball hit into play to a particular square on the gameboard. The amount of squares closest to a positioned fielder and the type of hit determine the result of that batted ball, according to a Results Chart. Result changes on the back of the next card can change the first result (and provide unusual results). Pitch choices include fast, curve, knuckle, screw, off speed, splitter, and slider. Players can decide how many of each type of hitter they want, and can designate a starter, 3 relievers, and a closer to have certain pitcher advantages.

Players can also elect to steal, try a pickoff, hit-and-run, or take an extra base on a hit. Certain pitchers can have a ball-strike advantage, and in two-strike situations, batters can try to outguess the pitcher by taking a pitch. Using a wind direction factor also is optional. When all 100 cards are played, players reshuffle the deck and start over.

Game comes with 4-color game board, 100 result cards, Results Chart, Guidelines, one Hit Ball marker, four pitch-count markers, 14 wooden player pieces for each team including 5 pieces with colored tops representing pinch-hitters, and scoresheets.

Name: Objetivo Moscú
Description:
The game simulates Operation Barbarossa, Nazi Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union during World War II that commenced on June 22, 1941.

The duration of the campaign is 15 turns (2 months each).

At the end of the 5th turn, the Axis Forces may win the game provided that they have control of Moscow, Leningrad and Stalingrad. Otherwise, the winner after the 15th turn is the one that: i) gets enemy's surrender at any time; ii) has a total amount of units 3-fold larger than the enemy's amount; iii) has more victory points (according to cities' values).

Game Components:

    80x64 cm board
    10-page rulebook
    1 die
    Counters representing armies involved in the conflict: Soviet, German, Finnish and Italian; Red Army and Wehrmacht tanks; Russian and German aviation
    City control markers

Name: Due Conga
Description:
Due Conga is an abstract two-player game using a board with four hollows and three varieties of eight stones.

In turn, each player places 1, 2 or 3 stones in one of four hollows. It is forbidden to have the same amount of stones in any of the hollows. The player who gets caught out or places the last stone is the loser.

Publishing history: Essen isn't only a place for publishers to find their gaming audience, sometimes it is also the place where designers find their dream publisher. Intrigued by a beautiful wooden version of Wittig's "Moguli", Frank Stark, with mainly card games and only one board game under his belt, got talking with the publisher and not much later Clemens Gerhards released two of his designs in the same high quality make-up. "Trio Trio" and "Samas" were followed a year later, in 2005, by "Kick-It" and "Due conGa", again in the deluxe wooden versions that are Clemens Gerhards' specialty.

Name: Democracy
Description:
Democracy: The Working of the Legislative Process

Democracy is actually three games in one.  The game is ment to be played in a classroom environment.  The first game is the Legislative Session, where players get to act roles and votes in the legislative process.  Game two is "Citizen's Action Meeting" where the players take roles of citizens and their actions towards compelling the representatives.  The third game is "Representative Democracy" which covers the voting and representative system.

The game contains many worksheets, petitions, cards and player aids.

Name: Ghetto
Description:
Ghetto (possibly also called Smelina) was a Monopoly variant set in the Terezin (Theresianstadt) Ghetto in what is now the Czech Republic. The game was designed in 1943 by Oswald Pöck, an engineer who was confined in the Ghetto at that time. Pöck produced the game for children who were confined in Terezin, and the game was passed from one child to another as they were taken from Terezin to the death camps.

Two copies of the game are known to exist: one at the Yad Vashem holocaust museum and another at the Beit Terezin museum.

Name: I-SPY
Description: A game with unusual equipment. One player is the "detective", he holds a special magnifying glass in which a tile is inserted. The magnifying glass only lets him or her see a tiny piece of the tile; so it has to be moved back and forth to find out what the tile shows. In the meantime, however, the other player are trying to roll a little metal ball into a hole on their special clocks, the hole having been determined by the detective first. As soon as a player has gotten the ball in the right hole, the detective has to show the picture from the tile on the game board, if successful, he or she can keep it. The magnifying glass is passed on to the next player. The player who wins most tiles wins the game.

Name: Atolla Modulis (fan expansion for Funkenschlag)
Description:
Atolla Modulis is a free modular expansion to Friedemann Friese's Power Grid (aka Funkenschlag 2nd Ed.). The Atolla Modulis system allows players to play a different game every time as there are thousands of possible combinations! Other than the initial setup, the Atolla Modulis plays with the same rules as the base game. A copy of Funkenschlag/Powergrid is required to play this expansion.

For helpful hints on building your own version, visit the BGG Wiki page on Print and Play Games

Name: Heroscape Expansion Set: Thaelenk Tundra
Description:
Thaelunk Tundra is the second Large Terrain Expansion Set (Wave 4.5) in the HeroScape series. It was released with the Figure Expansion Raknar's Vision.

There is 1 large booster pack:

     Glacier Mountains, Ice and Snow Pack with Snow Hunters


Content:

6 glaciers

6 glacier ice bases

21 ice tiles

12 single-hex

12 double-hex snow tiles

Name: Heroscape Expansion Set: Raknar's Vision
Description:
Raknar's Vision is the second Large Figure Expansion Set (wave 4.5) in the HeroScape series. It was released with Thaelenk Tundra.

There is 1 large booster pack:

     Heroes of Lindesfarme

Name: Seven Seas
Description:
This is an economics game about the world-wide shipping business.

At the start of the game, each player gets some cash, a B-class merchant ship (which can later be upgraded to A-class), and the choice of a home port. A-class ships move faster and carry more cargo, but cannot navigate the Suez or Panama Canals. The home port is important, because it counts as a permanent trade contract and many of the game functions can only be carried out there.

During the game, players draw destination cards and cargoes, which can then be bought from the bank. Cargoes can only be sold in one of the destinations - each card has 3 to choose from. Players can also buy trade contracts for the ports, which brings in more profit when selling cargo there and forces other players to pay fees when visiting those ports. At the start of the game there's a basic profit for selling cargo; stock market fluctuations (event cards) may later change this.

Movement at sea is by die rolling. A 1 or a 6 result in drawing an event card, which may be positive or negative and may affect other players also. 
Events include icebergs, hurricanes, carrying Royal Mail, competing for the Blue Ribbon prize, accidents, smuggling etc.

A player that loses her ship or goes bankrupt must turn to piracy, at least temporarily. Piracy may be profitable, but also carries a score penalty at the end of the game.

Players can also buy insurance to protect against losses, or convert cash into gold bullion which is safer from market fluctuations and other hazards.

The game ends as soon as any player decides to end it by calling out "Stand By". All players now make their way back to their home ports, where all their assets are converted back to cash; winner is the player who has amassed the biggest fortune by any means available in the game.

Name: Descent: The Well of Darkness
Description:
This is the first expansion for Descent.  It includes new monsters (with figures), heroes, treasures, effects, scenarios, props, and more!  It also features options for the Overlord player to customize his deck for each scenario.

Deep in the bowels of the world, there lies a chasm that was sealed over a millennium ago. Within it lies a force of evil so great that, were it to be unleashed, it would plunge the world into a thousand years of darkness.

Before you can face that challenge, however, you'll battle your way through dank tunnels, trapped temples, and even volcanoes to prove your worth. You'll face a host of new tricks, traps, and other lethal obstacles over the course of your quest, including scything blades, rolling boulders, and boiling hot lava.

Descent: the Well of Darkness features six new heroes, tricky kobolds, bloodsucking ferrox, and unstoppable golems. Heroes will find more skill and treasures at their disposal, including six new relics and a new type of potion. The Overlord, on the other hand, gains the ability to customize his deck before every game, putting in devastating new trap, event, and spawn cards.
Families: Game: Descent – Journeys in the Dark

Name: Solution
Description: Promotional game about communications - players have to built a network by using competent resource, media and communication methods. Game has nice wooden components.

Name: Verðbréfaspilið
Description:
A family game for 10 years old and up. The goal is to become the Chairman of Iceland.
To achieve that goal, players buy and sell stock, bonds and private companies, and seek to become major stock holders in each company.
Players' money can be stored in a bank or taken as a loan, both options with interest.
Players can hold auctions to sell their stock, and they can also make an offer for other's stock.
The game ends when one player owns everything and becomes the Chairman of Iceland.
